comments.commentBody:
well if "quality of life" is based on your square footage of your home then yes... of all the cities you named NYC is safer (not sure of Raleigh) from a crime and even many health indicators. None of those cities have the cultural or educational assets of NYC. None of them offers the dynamism of NYC on many levels. If those things matter then NYC is THE place. If not - then absolutely it is a free country and you can move anywhere. If you want to work in the energy sector - Nashville is not the place for you. Likewise if you want to work for the top publishers then you would look in NYC rather than Charlotte.
There is a reason NYC is more expensive than those places. If you want to just live "anywhere" then sure the country and world are full of options. Frank Sinatra wasn't singing about just being a part of "anywhere" though.
I came here from Cleveland, that's why.

Unless one is making a ton of money or needs to stay in region for family reasons, I'd recommend people not be afraid to leave the NYC metro area.  Other cities in the country such as Dallas, Atlanta, Houston, Nashville, Charlotte, Raleigh, Indianapolis, etc... -- all offer a far superior quality of life for *middle class* people than the New York City area.  They all have quality housing which is incredibly affordable, all within the vicinity of good job markets (to the extent that such exist today), nice restaurants, shopping and even some nice cultural amenities believe it or not.  One can acquire quality housing for $100,000 - $150,000 in these cities, and near luxury housing relatively speaking in these cities for $200,000 - $300,000 a year -- whereas $600,000 in many NYC neighborhoods doesn't buy much more than a dump relatively speaking.  So why stay unless there are just ties that bind that can't be broken?

This is exactly why we bought in the Bronx. The house net to may parents in Windsor Terrace was on the market for $1M+, it finally sold for $800K, then the people sank about $500K into it by re-doing the entire front (necessary - my parents had to do the same thing) and gut-renovating. Who has that kind of money?!
Karen, thanks for pointing that out, you're exactly right!  And they always end up spending way more than what their initial budget was!
They are not rushing because it is so far away.

Don't you ever write about normal people? As in normal people who can't possibly afford 900k houses? Articles like this one make this paper look incredibly out of touch with the average metro area resident.
The real shame is that Americans don't have NHC, not that Canadians like their so much they do what it takes to keep it.
Newark is incredibly ugly with horrendous schools and ridiculously high properly taxes. I have no idea why anyone rational would want to live there.
Hate to break it to you, but that Fort Greene brownstone is worth $4 million. You could have leveraged that value and bought all of those other properties as well.
And it's 98 degrees in Texas on a colder day. No thank you.

Theres lots of posts saying if new yorkers move to ____ (fill in your state, city, country, continent) they will save $$ and have a bigger place, etc. Most people in New York already know that. The article is for people who want to remain within the city.  They have their reasons for wanting I stay.
I live in Bed-Stuy. It takes me 15 minutes to get to lower Manhattan and I can park on the street, easily. Upper West Side? No thank you.
The IOC does not favor the US in general, perhaps the reverse is more correct to those who have followed their decisions in the past.

The advantages of being a client state in display.   If what has transpired at the Fukushima complex -- with the lies, misinformation and ineptitude -- occurred in Russia or China or any nation that is not a US client, Japan would not have gotten the Olympics.  The dearth of coverage of this extreme environmental catastrophe speaks volumes of global alliances.   Bad choice IOC.

Ed Peritz, Sept. 5th post

Dear Mr. Peritz,

Mr. Benson is quite correct.

Galileo, when confronted with the strong possibility that he would be burned at the stake if he persisted in his logical conclusion that the earth was not the center of the universe, wrote the following in his Recantation of June 22,1633,

"...I have been... suspected of heresy, that is, of having held and believed that the Sun is the center of the universe and immovable, and that the earth is not the center of the same, and that it does move...I abjure with a sincere heart and unfeigned faith, I curse and detest the said errors and heresies, and generally all and every error and sect contrary to the Holy Catholic Church."

Thereafter Galileo made himself scarce and secreted himself in his villa until the end of his life. He gave his opinion on scientific matters to visitors who came to see him, but never again committed anything to paper.

Let no one condemn him who has not had a lighted match inserted unwillingly between his toes.

'The next phase of the campaign will be more individualized, and more from Mr. Obama himself. Democrats who are balking are being asked at least to vote against Republican procedural moves meant to delay or derail an up-or-down vote. After all the arguments are exhausted, aides said, it will come down to a personal pitch: the president needs you to save him from a debilitating public defeat.'

~ New York Times, Obama’s Battle for Syria Votes, Taut and Uphill
It states very clearly that the measure is real economic output per person. Also, fewer than half of teenagers attended high school until  1940, so Glendale high school must have been the exception.

This is so wonderful and carefully written. I guess the care was taken so that Prof. Stiglitz can't be accused of sour grapes. After much grousing it seemed the US had finally gotten rid of Rahm and Timmy so it is really alarming to see a potential return of Summers. It is almost a contemptuous gesture towards the 99% to consider putting Larry Summers in the Fed post. What progressives and left-Democrats have to take notice of is the people who support Summers for the job despite writing and talking about inequality and unemployment. Can they really be trusted to seek the public good over their own career needs or their need to support their colleagues?
Political games are the stuff of primetime cable "news" and can stay there.  Thoughtful analysis like this, covering world events with the depth they deserve, is why I read the New York Times.

Mr. Summers has indeed, "been there" during a crises or two, largely because his advice helped create them. Appointing Larry Summers Chairman of the Federal Reserve based on his experience with emergencies is like hiring an arsonist to head the fire department because he understands how to burn things to the ground.

It's not merely that Mr. Summers has shown incredibly poor predictive powers when consider the ramifications of his own policy failure, or that his demonstrated prejudice toward women (in terms of their math skills anyway), indicates a highly fallible mind; it's that Mr. Summers never truly seems to acknowledge his mistakes. Yes, he is obviously a genius, as even he seems inclined to admit, but does that make him a leader? I've know plenty of extra smart people to whom I would never even consider loaning my car, much less my savings. I don't think the guy who pushed, pushed, pushed deregulation of the banking industry should be given control of ALL our money. Ms. Yellen would be the responsible choice, and one who would care about the nation's reputation as much as her own.
Beasly is a gutsy guy. Time for him to make way (assuming there is someone worthy of the spot) every champ needs an e it strategy

akichichira - I think your English is fine.  Many of us scientist around the world have been very concerned about Fukushima - from day one - not just now with the current issues of leaking contaminated water.  I hope the Tokyo Olympic win will give the Japanese people some sense of relief from all the tragedies they have faced since 2011 yet not distract from the urgency and seriousness 150 miles to the north.

I would have loved to see Madrid win, but with its economy still in deep recession, it's doubtful if it could even muster enough resources for new facilities and infrastructure necessary for the Game.

Tokyo is indeed the safe choice, at least Japan has most a lot of facilities already in place. Economics is a real concern. I don't mean to disparage, but one doesn't need to look much further, than what happens in Brazil right now, in its preparedness (or lack thereof) in the World Cup and the Olympics. It's a shame, really.

Unsure about the other cities but the Sydney post-Olympic hangover/curse never eventuated.  The stadiums are used on a regular basis for sports/concerts and the previous athlete's villages are now vibrant communities.  Happy that Australia won and had the privileged to host the Games.  Congrats to Japan!

Err...there are no empty stadiums in London as the venues are currently being transformed into post Olympic venues. This is currently happening with the Aquatic center, the Stadium and the Velodrome. The rest were temporary venues that got dismantled after the games,  or venues that existed prior to the Games (i.e. EXCEL Center, Earls Court, the O2, Wimbledon etc).

Being awarded Olympics is a curse in disguise.  Just look at the all the empty stadiums in Montreal, Athens, Sydney, London...etc., and with tens of billions of debt to be repaid, just to have 2 weeks of glory.  I hope American cities are done with even thinking about hosting the games.
And you seem to forget that the 1984 Olympics actually had 280 million surplus...

I would like to extend Mr. Zaslavsky’s question about who can wear Altuzarra’s evening gowns, to include other designers and their size ‘too small and below’ collections.

Sadly, but not surprisingly, the answer is: the impressionable young; those who are in the midst (and sometimes mist) of imaging, of designing and creating their own identities. "Identity vs. Role Confusion" is the phrase developmental psychologist, Erik Erikson, formulated to describe the challenge and tension at this stage of an individual’s psychosocial development.

As I see it, the message is: thin, aloof; pretentiously (and precariously) perched on 7-inch heels is how to earn a Summa prize for beauty, approval, happiness and success.

Ironically, Humpty Dumpty and where he sat comes to mind. In the spirit of innovative healthcare, cost saving solutions, I suggest shorter walls: no more than two feet.
Who, other than professional, anorexic models with carefully colored hair and face, can wear these evening dresses?

I think you got your micros mixed up with microns.

Tokyo's radiation level as of Sept. 5, 2013 is 0.000066 mSv/hr. or 0.00066 rem/hr. which is the equivalent to 0.47 rems per year. FYI, the radiation level in Tokyo prior to the Fukushima accident ranged between 0.20 to 0.56 rems per year.

Tokyo's radiation level is being monitored daily, and is no different than that of New York.
